urn:contentItem:5T4S-N741-JB20-G0ND-00000-00Google It; Ohr in Hot Water; Arizona Primary; Florida Primaries; Midterm Monkey Wrench; Rouhani under Fire; Power Play; Pope under Pressure; Archbishop Calls on Pope Francis to Resign Amid Church Sex Abuse Scandal; President Trump Criticizes Google's Search Algorithm; Bruce Ohr Testifies Before Congress; Florida Holds Primary for Gubernatorial Race; Ordered Redistricting for North Carolina Could Delay Election2018-08-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:55:45ZLexisNexisFOX SPECIAL REPORT WITH BRET BAIER6:00 PM ESTSusan PageNEWSDomestic082801cb.254Google It; Ohr in Hot Water; Arizona Primary; Florida Primaries; Midterm Monkey Wrench; Rouhani under Fire; Power Play; Pope under Pressure; Archbishop Calls on Pope Francis to Resign Amid Church Sex Abuse Scandal; President Trump Criticizes Google's Search Algorithm; Bruce Ohr Testifies Before Congress; Florida Holds Primary for Gubernatorial Race; Ordered Redistricting for North Carolina Could Delay ElectionBret Baier, John Roberts, Catherine Herridge, Peter Doocy, Jonathan Serrie, Benjamin Hall, Jennifer Griffin, Lauren Green, Byron York, Mollie Hemingway

DANA PERINO, FOX NEWS HOST: But in 95 degree heat --

TAMMY BRUCE, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Or ice tea then or --

JUAN WILLIAMS, FOX NEWS HOST: But they use real pumpkin --

BRUCE: Yes. They use real pumpkin and you can get pumpkin scones. You can get like a cookie in the shape of an owl --

PERINO: The whole thing.

BRUCE: -- that's a pumpkin. So welcome to fall. And enjoy the pumpkin spice latte.

GREG GUTFELD, FOX NEWS HOST: All right. Set your DVRs. Never miss an episode of THE FIVE.

SPECIAL REPORT up next. Hey -- Bret.

BRET BAIER, FOX NEWS ANCHOR: Greg -- thanks. Welcome to a very hot White House north lawn.

Aiming high -- President Trump picks a fight with the world's largest company.

A Justice Department official is grilled about his ties to the author of the Trump dossier.

And could the Catholic sex abuse scandal bring down the Pope?

This is SPECIAL REPORT.

Good evening. I'm Bret Baier. We're coming to you live tonight from the White House north lawn.

The President here is once again taking on news and social media. In fact, if you do a Google search on the words "Trump" and "Google" you get results with words like "rage", "rigged", and "conspiracy theory".

President Trump is not happy with Google over what he calls suppression of conservative voices and positive news about his administration.

Chief White House correspondent John Roberts has specifics tonight. Thanks for having us again.

JOHN ROBERTS, FOX NEWS CHIEF WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT: Bret -- good evening to you. Welcome to the sauna bath --

BAIER: Yes.

ROBERTS: -- in Pennsylvania.

Officials from Google, Facebook, and Twitter are going to be testifying on Capitol Hill next week. The issue was foreign interference in the election. But there are certainly a few questions that President Trump would like to ask him if he had the chance.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

ROBERTS: Its corporate motto is "Do the right thing", but today President Trump accused Google of doing the wrong thing, of twisting search results to highlight negative stories about him and suppress conservative voices.

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I think Google is really taking advantage of a lot of people and I think it's a very serious thing and it's a very serious charge.

ROBERTS: The President singled out not just Google but Facebook and Twitter too.

TRUMP: You just can't do that. They're really treading on very, very troubled territory. And they have to be careful. It's not fair to large portions of the population.

ROBERTS: The Oval Office remarks followed a morning Twitter rant where the President said it might be illegal, insisting "this is a very serious situation, will be addressed".

A Google search of the words "Trump news" yields mostly stories regarding his complaints about Google including one that debunked his claim. But there is also a Vanity Fair article that comes up with the headline "Trump is nuts". Google denies any attempt to eliminate the positive and accentuate the negative.

NICK ZAKRASEK, GOOGLE PRODUCT MANAGER: Search is not used to set a political agenda. And we don't bias our results towards any political ideology.

ROBERTS: President Trump also drew a sharp response from Mexico today. One day after cutting a new trade deal, the President said a border wall will be built and Mexico will pay for it.

TRUMP: The wall will be paid for very easily by Mexico. It will ultimately be paid for by Mexico.

ROBERTS: Mexico begged to differ. In a tweet Mexico's foreign minister saying "We just reached a trade understanding with the U.S. and the outlook for the relationship between our two countries is very positive. We will never pay for a wall however. That has been absolutely clear from the very beginning."

The wall dispute aside, the Mexico trade deal certainly got Canada's attention. The foreign minister came calling in Washington today after President Trump threatened a 25 percent tariff on Canadian-built cars if it didn't sign on to a revised NAFTA.

The President's chief economic advisor denied that the White House was putting pressure on Canada and other U.S. trade allies but freely acknowledged the ultimate goal is to twist a few arms in Beijing.

LARRY KUDLOW, WHITE HOUSE CHIEF ECONOMIC ADVISOR: I think China is now on the defensive because they see that the USA is beginning to get some momentum. And I think that's great.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

ROBERTS: The President's Democratic critics though are skeptical of this deal with Mexico. The Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer saying well maybe it's something like the North Korean deal. Looks good on the surface but very little detail and who knows what's really going to happen -- Bret?

BAIER: You know, last night the President had a dinner for evangelical leaders and there was a line in there that is catching some attention.

ROBERTS: Yes. There's a tape out, somebody put out a recording -- apparently the President said something to the effect of if Democrats take control of Congress they will quickly and violently overturn everything that has been done.

I spoke with Pastor Robert Jeffress a short time ago. He was there. He thought the President was using "violent" as more of a metaphor to talk about what the Democrats would do, not suggesting that there would be rioting in the streets. Jeffress himself says he was invited to come up and spoke to the crowd.

He said that if Democrats take control of Congress he believes one of two things will happen. They will either try to throw the President out of office or they will handcuff him and his administration so he won't be able to get anything done for the next two years.

BAIER: John -- thank you.

ROBERTS: Thanks -- Bret.

BAIER: Well, stock today finished ahead. The Dow was up 14, the S&P 500 gained one, the Nasdaq jumped 2 or rather 12. The last two -- S&P 500 and Nasdaq, the highest records there for those two indices.

One of the Americans behind the infamous Trump dossier was on Capitol Hill today trying to explain the complicated web of intrigue and information surrounding that document.

The fact that Bruce Ohr is still a high-ranking Justice Department official and his wife worked for the company behind the dossier made the situation, as you can imagine, even more precarious.

Chief intelligence correspondent Catherine Herridge reports from Capitol Hill.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Mr. Ohr, were you acting alone? Or did you have a story from a Justice Department official? How did your wife benefit from the dossier contract?

CATHERINE HERRIDGE, FOX NEWS CHIEF INTELLIGENCE CORRESPONDENT: Justice Department official Bruce Ohr, whose portfolio included drugs and gangs not Russia, ignored Fox's questions as he arrived on Capitol Hill. With a closed-door deposition underway, Republican lawmakers said Ohr told his FBI contact there were issues with the Trump dossier and its author former British spy Christopher Steele who had an anti-Trump bias.

Sources tell Fox News the evidence suggests the national security court was kept in the dark when it authorized a surveillance warrant for Trump campaign aide Carter Page.

SENATOR MARK MEADOWS (R), NORTH CAROLINA: Not only did the FBI know that the dossier was unverified but they also knew that there was real credibility issues.

HERRIDGE: Another lawmaker said Ohr's answers about the timing and handling of the dossier do not line up with other witnesses including former FBI lawyer Lisa Page who sent anti-Trump texts and Glenn Simpson whose firm fusion GPS was paid by the DNC and Clinton campaign for the anti-Trump research.

REP. MATT GAETZ (R), FLORIDA: There are a number of factual conflicts. Either Bruce Ohr is lying or Glenn Simpson is lying. And in another circumstance, either Bruce Ohr is lying or Lisa Page is lying.

ROBERTS: After the FBI fired Steele as a source over his media contacts, documents show Steele used Ohr as a back-channel to maintain contact with the bureau and pass along information. Ohr's wife Nellie worked for Fusion GPS on Russia, lawmakers point to a financial conflict.

REP. DARRELL ISSA (R), CALIFORNI: Although Bruce Ohr would appear to claim to be without partisan, his wife since 2015 knowingly worked on the "find dirt on Trump" -- try to make this connection with the Russians for which she was paid and he didn't properly disclose.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

HERRIDGE: The Ohr deposition concluded here just an hour ago after seven hours of grilling. Democratic lawmakers did not attend, leaving the questioning to their staffers and lawyers -- Bret.

BAIER: Catherine Herridge on the Hill. Catherine -- thank you.

The second trial of former Trump campaign chairman Paul Manafort is being pushed back a week. The judge has granted a defense motion. Opening statements will now begin September 24th. Jury selection gets underway September 17th. Last week Manafort was convicted on eight counts of fraud and other crimes.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell says he will form a bipartisan panel to solicit ideas on the best way to honor his former colleague John McCain. The Arizona senator died Saturday, some Senators support renaming the Russell Senate Office Building for McCain.

On the senate floor today, in an emotional speech, Senator Lindsey Graham, his longtime friend McCain he said will be impossible to replace.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SENATOR LINDSEY GRAHAM (R), SOUTH CAROLINA: I'm going to need your help, and the void to be filled by John's passing is more than I can do. Don't look to me to replace this man. Look to me to remember what he was all about and try to follow in his footsteps.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: McCain will lie in state at Arizona's capital tomorrow on what would have been his 82nd birthday before being transferred to the U.S. Capitol Friday.

In America's Election Headquarters tonight, voters casting primary ballots right now in Arizona, Florida and Oklahoma. In the Sooner State, two Republicans who want to be governor are try to out-Trump each other, the governor's race in Florida is also drawing major interest.

Phil Keating is in Orlando with more on that. First up though Peter Doocy in Tempe, Arizona and the Republican senate primary that will set up one of the most-watched general election senate races in the country. Good evening -- Peter.

PETER DOOCY, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Good evening -- Bret. At the first polling place we visited first thing this morning, a worker came out and asked our crew if we were there to fix their stuff. As it turns out the contractor hired by Maricopa County, the largest county in the state, that was supposed to be setting up voting machines didn't show up to set them up everywhere. And there were hundreds of calls of complaints first thing this morning for this primary that could tilt control of the Senate according to the Republican front runner in the GOP primary Martha McSally.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARTHA MCSALLY (R), ARIZONA SENATE CANDIDATE: Arizona is a firewall state. If they have any chance to flip the majority, it goes through Arizona. I'm the firewall to make sure that Chuck Schumer, Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders are not in charge in the Senate.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOOCY: Joining McSally on the ballot are Dr. Kelly Ward and Sheriff Joe Arpaio. The winner is likely to face Democratic Congresswoman Kyrsten Sinema in November.

Remember, this is the contest that made Jeff Flake want to call it a career. He said last August, "The path I would have to travel to get the Republican nomination is a path I'm not willing to take. It would require me to believe in positions I don't hold on such issues as trade and immigration; and it would require me to condone behaviors that I cannot condone."

But even though the front runner to replace him is the most moderate person on the ballot, Flake says he has no regrets about not seeking reelection.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SENATOR JEFF FLAKE (R), ARIZONA: This is the President's party, much to my consternation and I think for the long-term detriment of the party. I hope that's not always the case but today this is the President's party.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOOCY: I asked McSally, the front runner if there were any similarities that she shared with Flake that she wanted to share then with primary voters. And she said she wasn't going to go there.

Now to our colleague Phil Keating in Florida -- Phil.

PHIL KEATING, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Peter -- more than $150 million have been spent this year on the gubernatorial race and President Trump plays a big factor in all of it.

Let's start with the Republicans. It's going to be three-term congressman Ron DeSantis versus former Congressman and current agriculture commissioner Adam Putnam. DeSantis took the apparent lead in the polls after winning Trump's ringing endorsement. Putnam spent twice as much money knocked on 400,000 and has a much better grassroots ground game which could help him tonight.

On the Democratic side, a big field of five -- Gwen Graham has been consistently pulling a lead of seven points or more. She is a former congresswoman, daughter of a former governor and senator, and thinks she alone can pull the female vote. Former Miami Beach Mayor Philip Levine spent $30 million of his own dollars on this race and showed up yesterday at the Jacksonville mass shooting to tout gun-control. And progressive Tallahassee Mayor Andrew Gillam hopes to become the state's first black governor and also has the Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont's endorsement.

And for the nationally followed senate race, the primary is already a done deal. So in November, two-term Republican Governor Rick Scott is hoping to unseat three-term Democrat Bill Nelson. Nelson -- a moderate, pro-gun control and former astronaut is considered vulnerable in losing this seat which he's held since 2000.

Governor Scott touts his record of job creation, has a huge money advantage and President Trump's full support. About two million Floridians have already voted in this primary either by mail or in person early. That could be likely more than half of the total turnout.

A big reason for that -- this is the first year in Florida since 1986 where both parties had a competitive primary to get to the governor's mansion -- Bret.

BAIER: Phil Keating, live in Orlando. Phil -- thank you. Our thanks to Peter Doocy as well in Arizona.

We may not know who wins North Carolina's House elections and by extension who controls the U.S. House of representatives until next year. Why is that?

Well, North Carolina has been ordered to redraw its congressional district map with just 70 days to go before the midterm elections.

Correspondent Jonathan Serrie is in our southeast bureau with the reason why and what that could all mean.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

JONATHAN SERRIE, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: In a ruling that could affect the balance of power in Congress, a panel of three federal judges has determined North Carolina's congressional district map is unconstitutional, gerrymandered to favor Republicans.

PHIL BERGER (R), NORTH CAROLINA STATE SENATE: I feel that the maps, as they are, are fair, that they were drawn consistent with the rules that have been in place for decades.

SERRIE: Advocacy groups challenged the maps in federal court saying the current system, which allows the party in power to set district boundaries, has the potential to disenfranchise voters.

BOB PHILLIPS, COMMON CAUSE NORTH CAROLINA: It's just not a good thing when lawmakers are drawing their own districts. The temptation is too great to game the system and that's what we have in North Carolina and unfortunately across America.

SERRIE: Ten of North Carolina's 13 congressional districts are in GOP hands. Republican state senate leader Phil Berger says the current system works.

BERGER: I think the fairest way to do it is to let the people elect the legislators and let the legislators draw the maps. That's been the system.

It was good enough for the Democrats when they were in control. It should be good enough now.

SERRIE: What's at stake goes beyond the boundaries of any particular district but the chaos it could cause in Congress. The court has yet to determine whether it will allow November's election to go forward using the current maps if the opinion the court says "We decline to rule out the possibility that the state should be enjoined from conducting any further congressional elections using the 2016 plan."

JASON HUSSER, ELON UNIVERSITY: It could definitely make the difference in several House races in North Carolina. And importantly, it could delay when we find out who actually wins the majority in the U.S. House of Representatives.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

SERRIE: The court is giving the parties in the case until 5:00 p.m. Friday to submit briefs arguing whether the maps need to be changed ahead of the November election and whether the general assembly should be allowed the first opportunity to redraw those districts -- Bret.

BAIER: Jonathan Serrie in our southeast bureau. Jonathan -- thank you.

Up next, almost a year after Hurricane Maria, the death toll in Puerto Rico keeps rising. We'll bring you that.

First, here's what some of our Fox affiliates around the country are covering tonight.

Fox 7 in Austin, Texas as the owner of a company that makes untraceable 3D printed guns says he has begun selling the blueprints through his Web site. Cody Wilson says he believes that by selling the plans instead of posting them online for anyone to view or download for free, he will not run afoul of a federal court order.

Fox 2 in St. Louis as Missouri lawmakers approved legislation banning companies from labeling lab grown meat products or meat substitutes as meat. A St. Louis newspaper reports the provision states a product cannot be marketed as meat if it is not derived from an animal with two or four feet.

And this is a live look at Detroit from our affiliate Fox 2. The big story there tonight, public viewings begin of the queen of soul before she is laid to rest later this week. Viewings for Aretha Franklin will take place tonight until 9:00 p.m. all day tomorrow and Thursday afternoon. Franklin's funeral will be held Friday and is limited to her family and friends. Aretha Franklin died August 16th at her home in Detroit from pancreatic cancer. She was 76.

That's tonight's live look outside the Beltway from SPECIAL REPORT -- we'll be right back to the White House after this.

BAIER: The Eisenhower Executive Office Building there in the background, named for the 34th president -- panning over to the west wing here on White House campus.

Meantime overseas, the pressure is increasing exponentially tonight for Iran's president. He was called before the Iranian parliament today and lawmakers there did not like what they heard about the prospects for fixing that nation's cratering economy.

Correspondent Benjamin Hall has the story.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BENJAMIN HALL, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Rare voices of dissent in the Iranian parliament today as MPs held President Rouhani to account for his handling of the economic crisis. This is just the second time in Iranian history that parliament had summoned the President to answer questions and four times today lawmakers voted against him showing signs of deep internal division.

As U.S. sanctions take hold and the rial plummets, Rouhani sought to blame the U.S. for the troubles.

HASSAN ROUHANI, PRESIDENT OF IRAN (through translator): We will not allow a bunch of anti-Iranians in the White House to plot against us.

HALL: After months of protests, pressure is also mounting among the public who are now feeling the effects of inflation waving (ph) questions about Rouhani's future.

In The Hague, it was day two of Iran's attempt to have sanctions suspended by the U.N. using a little known friendship agreement from 1955. They called the sanctions economic strangulation. The U.S. defended the sanctions saying they were legal and justified as a national security measure.

JENNIFER GILLIAN NEWSTEAD, STATE DEPARTMENT LEGAL ATTACHE: Iran sought to characterize itself as a victim, as a law-abiding state brought to its knees by unlawful U.S. sanctions. The suggestion that Iran is a victim does not withstand scrutiny at any level.

HALL: Nor does the U.S. military have any doubt about the Iranian's true intentions, today accusing them of supporting terrorists and brutal regimes.

JAMES MATTIS, U.S. SECRETARY OF DEFENSE: Fundamentally, they continue to be the single biggest destabilizing element in the Middle East.

HALL: And as if to prove it, Iran has just signed a new security deal with Syria. The defense minister arriving in Damascus saying they have no intention of pulling their troops out.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

HALL: And in another blow for Iran, in news just breaking on Reuters, France -- one of the few countries trying to keep the Iran deal alive has told its diplomats not to travel to the country, citing a foiled bomb plot by Iranian agents in Paris at an event attended by Rudy Giuliani back in June -- Bret.

BAIER: Benjamin Hall in London. Benjamin -- thank you.

As tensions rise again with North Korea, the Defense Department is saying it is continuing to prepare to defend its allies in the region.

National security correspondent Jennifer Griffin tells us about it from the Pentagon.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

JENNIFER GRIFFIN, FOX NEWS NATIONAL SECURITY CORRESPONDENT: Just days after President Trump abruptly canceled Secretary of State Mike Pompeo's trip to North Korea and Pyongyang threatened to resume missile tests, Defense Secretary James Mattis said there are no plans to suspend future large-scale military exercises with South Korea and other Asian allies.

Is it time to restart military exercises with South Korea given the recent news that the North Koreans are not denuclearizing?

MATTIS: We took the step to suspend several of the largest exercises as a good faith measure coming out of the Singapore summit. We have no plans at this time to suspend any more exercises.

GRIFFIN: During the Singapore summit, President Trump referred to these military exercises as provocative war games and agreed to suspend three that would be taking place now including Freedom Guardians, an annual exercise dating back to 1976.

Last year 17,500 U.S. service members took part with eight other countries. The next tier one military exercise known as Fall Eagle is slated for February.

MATTIS: We suspended several of the largest exercises but we did not suspend the rest. So there are ongoing exercises all the time on the Peninsula.

GRIFFIN: Japan today reiterated its plans to bolster its missile defense calling North Korea an ongoing serious threat.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

GRIFFIN: The President canceled Pompeo's trip to North Korea after receiving what he perceived as a belligerent letter by a secret North Korean channel. Today at the State Department spokeswoman Heather Nauert read another letter, this one from Pompeo to North Korea saying America stands ready to engage when the time is right -- Bret.

BAIER: Jennifer Griffin at the Pentagon. Jennifer -- thank you.

Up next, is the Pope in trouble over the church's sex abuse scandal? We'll bring you that story.

First, beyond our borders tonight.

Several Latin American countries are reportedly getting ready to join the International Criminal Court in determining whether to put Venezuelan officials on trial for crimes against humanity. That's according to Univision tonight. The countries named are Argentina, Colombia, and Chile. Venezuela is, of course, suffering from an economic and political crisis under socialist President Nicolas Maduro.

A United Nations report says the governments of Yemen, the United Arab Emirates, and Saudi Arabia may have been responsible for war crimes during three years of battling rebels in Yemen. That report saying that crimes include raping, torture, kidnapping, and murder. They also note possible crimes committed by the Iran aligned rebels known as the Houthis.

French police say a man suspected of viciously slapping a 22-year-old woman last month near a Paris cafe has been arrested. The victim became a symbol of sexual harassment after surveillance cameras captured the attack. That happened when the victim told the man to shut up for making obscene sounds at her. French media reports the suspect had been receiving psychiatric treatment at a Paris hospital.

Just some of the other stories beyond our borders tonight. We'll be right back to the White House after this.

BAIER: Welcome back to the White House.

There is growing concern tonight that the Catholic Church's sex abuse scandal could impact the highest leadership at the Vatican. Maybe even the Pope himself.

Religion Correspondent, Lauren Green has the latest.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

JOSH SHAPIRO, PENNSYLVANIA ATTORNEY GENERAL: A systematic cover-up at the highest levels --

LAUREN GREEN, FOX NEWS RELIGION CORRESPONDENT: Although he can't say what Pope Francis personally may or may not have known, Pennsylvania Attorney General Josh Shapiro asserts he has evidence the Vatican knew about the priests' sexual abuse.

SHAPIRO: The facts and the evidence in this grand jury report clearly show that the bishops and other church officials notified the Vatican of these predator priests. What happened after that, I don't know.

GREEN: Vatican spokesperson Greg Burke told FOX News we'll need more details about the prosecutor's claims before commenting. The attorney general's allegations come in the wake of an 11-page letter from former Vatican ambassador to the U.S. Archbishop Carlo Maria Vigano, who has been a Pope Francis critic. Vigano claims there is a homosexual current in the Vatican subverting Catholic doctrine, and that in 2013, Pope Francis asked him about the now defrocked and disgraced Cardinal McCarrick. Vigano says he told the Pope the bishops had a thick dossier on McCarrick, that he corrupted generations of seminarians and priests. The Pope refused to answer the charges.

POPE FRANCIS (through translator): I think the statement speaks for itself, and you have sufficient journalistic capacity to reach your own conclusions.

GREEN: Shapiro's claims follow a two-year grand jury investigation in Pennsylvania uncovering more than 300 predator priests and over 1,000 young victims going back to the 1940s.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

GREEN: Shapiro says since the grand jury report released a week ago, Pennsylvania's clergy abuse hotline has received more than 730 calls. Meanwhile, the American Catholic Bishops Review Board is calling for a full investigation of sexual misconduct within the church. Bret?

BAIER: We'll continue to follow that story. Lauren, thank you.

An independent investigation ordered by Puerto Rico's government estimates that 2,975 people died within six months as a result of hurricane Maria. These findings from the Milken Institute School of Public Health at George Washington University contrasts sharply, obviously, with the government official death toll of 64. It's also about double the government's previous interim estimate of 1,400.

New cases of sexually transmitted diseases rose nearly 10 percent in 2017 in the U.S., hitting record highs for a fourth straight year. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the CDC, says nearly 2.3 million new cases of chlamydia, gonorrhea, and syphilis were diagnosed last year.

The panel is next. As we go to break, President Trump commemorates the 55th anniversary of the "I Have a Dream" speech by Dr. Martin Luther King Jr, saying the nation reaffirms its commitment to protecting the promise of America for all its people. Fifty-five years ago tonight, Dr. King spoke from the Lincoln Memorial.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DR. MARTIN LUTHER KING: I have a dream that my four little children will one day live in a nation where they will not be judged by the color of their skin but by the content of their character. I have a dream today.

(APPLAUSE)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Google is really taking advantage of a lot of people, and I think that's a very serious thing, that's a very serious charge. They better be careful because you can't do that to people. You can't do it. We have tremendous, we have literally thousands and thousands of complaints coming in, and you just can't do that. so I think that Google and Twitter and Facebook, they're really treading on very, very troubled territory.

NICK ZAKRASEK, GOOGLE PRODUCT MANAGER: The search is not used to set a political agenda, and we don't bias our results towards any political ideology. We continually work to improve Google search and we never rank results to manipulate political sentiment.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: Google was on the mind today here at the White House. The president tweeting out this morning and then talking to the media, saying "Google's search results for "Trump News" shows only the viewing/reporting of fake news media. In other words, they have it rigged for me and others so that almost all stories and news is bad. Fake CNN is prominent. Republican, conservative, and fair media is shut out. Illegal? 96 percent of results on "Trump News" are from national leftwing media, very dangerous. Google and others are suppressing voices of conservatives and hiding information and news that is good. They are controlling what we can and cannot see. This is a very serious situation, will be addressed."

We'll start there with our panel, Byron York, chief political correspondent for the "Washington Examiner," Susan Page, Washington bureau chief at "USA Today," and Mollie Hemingway, senior editor at "The Federalist." Susan, your initial thoughts on this.

SUSAN PAGE, WASHINGTON BUREAU CHIEF, "USA TODAY": I think the problem that President Trump is seeing when he Googles his own name is that mainstream news sources and sources that are often linked by a lot of people come up first in the search. So it's not leftwing news sources. It's the mainstream news sources that people rely on. The analysis by a conservative group that took a fault with the algorithm that Google uses ranked "USA Today" as a leftwing news source, and I can tell you that is not accurate.

BAIER: Mollie?

MOLLIE HEMINGWAY, SENIOR EDITOR, "THE FEDERALIST": In the same way that you shouldn't just take what President Trump is saying about Google news and how they rank things as the gospel truth, neither should you accept Google's denials, particularly when you have this history of Google admitting that they de-rank based on their own conceptions, editorial conceptions. You have examples of them censoring in other countries. You have them dealing with a lawsuit in their own company, of dealing with their extreme leftwing bias. And they fired employees who were too conservative. You have Eric Schmidt admitting that de-ranking is used to help out some search results over others.

We have a piece up at "The Federalist" that shows that someone who has appeared on FOX News and CNN, his evidence that his FOX News appearances were devalued and his CNN appearances valued higher. So I think there's a lot more that needs to be studied about their algorithms and particularly how when you have a company that has employed almost exclusively progressives or liberals, how that might affect the algorithms that they create.

BAIER: Obviously, as you said, Google is pushing back hard against that. Byron, in the campaign, Donald Trump was listed as the most digitally savvy candidate, and his Google searches and all of his searches were tops. As your president, obviously the volume of stories dealing with a whole range of subjects increases.

BRYON YORK, CHIEF POLITICAL CORRESPONDENT, "WASHINGTON EXAMINER": Some of this is just Trump venting. It's part of his general pushback against the press. But conservatives really have had complaints against the big tech companies in recent years. Facebook has made an outreach to conservatives, talking to them, trying to convince them that their algorithms are fair. The CEO of Twitter has basically said, yes, we are all on the left.

As far as this concern, it's really very, very difficult to see, to tell definitively if these algorithms are biased or what. But I do think one thing will happen here. When the tech companies are under attack either from left or right, they will go to safety. They will start featuring the most mainstream news organizations, "The New York Times," "The Washington Post," which are precisely the news outlets that conservatives accuse of bias. So the problem will continue and we will hear more complaints about this.

BAIER: So down the row, Byron, Susan, Mollie, do you think some regulation on Google or other companies is coming?

YORK: What President Trump says is not the only example of people calling for this sort of regulation. I do think something is on the way in the next few years.

PAGE: I think there will be some more regulation of the big tech companies, although not necessarily because of the complaint that President Trump levied today. There are complaints about privacy, the handling of real fake news by these big tech companies. Yes, I think there is an appetite to try to do more to regulate some aspects of this business.

HEMINGWAY: Big tech companies are extremely worried about deregulation, and the answer of saying private companies can do whatever they want isn't going to be sufficient for a lot of people who think that they are putting too heavy of a hand on the dial particularly when it comes to political discussions and electoral results.

BAIER: We talked yesterday about the NAFTA and the Mexico situation. I want to move on to Bruce Ohr who is testifying behind closed doors on Capitol Hill today, Justice Department official at the center of that infamous Trump dossier, his wife worked for Fusion GPS, talking to lawmakers today. Here is Mark Meadows on Bruce Ohr's testimony.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. MARK MEADOWS, (R) CHAIRMAN, HOUSE FREEDOM CAUCUS: Not only did the FBI know that the dossier was unverified, but they also knew that there were real credibility issues where it would never end up in a courtroom. Bruce Ohr worked for the department of justice since 1991, and never in his entire history was anything handled in the way that this was handled.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: Setting that up, Meadows tweeted "We've learned new information suggesting our suspicions are true. FBI, DOJ have previously leaked info to the press and then used those same press stories as a separate source to justify FISA's unreal. Tomorrow's Bruce Ohr interview is even more critical. Did he ever do this."

Mollie, we're hearing he had a lot of lack of memory in this testimony, but we'll see where this goes.

HEMINGWAY: We're hearing the testimony contradicting the sworn testimony of other players in this drama. We don't know what happened because it was behind closed doors, but unfortunately that previous hearing with Peter Strzok was such a clown show that I think that people figured they needed it to be behind closed doors in order to get information. That comes at the expense of transparency for the American public.

What we are hearing is that he did admit that he was profiting from Fusion GPS. That was the firm that employed his wife to the tune of $44,000 while funneling information from Fusion GPS that was this Hillary Clinton concocted dossier of Russia conclusion. And as people have noted, this is a very unorthodox. This is not the way it people traditionally handle the investigation. He ostensibly had nothing to do with the investigation while he was funneling this information. So I think we have a lot of questions we need answered.

BAIER: Susan, what are the chances that Bruce Ohr stays on at the Justice Department after all this and the president's focus?

PAGE: What are the chances Jeff Sessions stays on at the Justice Department after all this? I don't know whether Bruce Ohr will stay in the Justice Department or not. And Congress certainly has a right and an obligation to pursue investigations as they see fit, but I would just note that we should remember the dossier was not the launching point for the Russia probe. George Papadopoulos talking at a London bar to an Australian diplomat was the launching point for this investigation. I think that's a fact that we should not lose sight of.

BAIER: Byron, last word.

YORK: I think Representative Meadows was saying the FBI knew about these problems with Michael Steele and the dossier, that Steele was desperate to get Donald Trump. I think they probably knew that because Bruce Ohr told them. And I think that what will come out of this is that the FBI knew well about the problems with Christopher Steele and his biases, even when it first applied for a FISA warrant to spy on Carter Page.

BAIER: And per our earlier conversation, "The Washington Post" tonight saying that the president vented twice, saying he might fire Sessions just in the past couple of weeks. We'll see where that goes.

Next up, the primaries and the midterms to come, plus one state that could throw everything up in the air.

REP. RON DESANTIS, (R) FLORIDA GUBERNATORIAL CANDIDATE: I think you're going to see a strong victory, but a victory that shows strength in all corners of Florida. We have a big, diverse state, and you've got to be able to compete in Miami. You've got to be able to compete Pensacola, and I think I've demonstrated that, and I think the results tonight will reflect that.

ADAM PUTMAN, (R) FLORIDA GUBERNATORIAL CANDIDATE: This is going to come down to a choice, a choice between the Washington way or putting Florida first.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: That race tonight should be interesting, the Florida governor primary where you have Ron DeSantis and Adam Putnam. You have three states with primaries tonight, voters are going to the polls in Arizona, in Oklahoma and Florida. But obviously this is all teeing up the midterm elections as we are closing in on that into the fall. We're back with the panel. I asked the panelists to pick a race that they are following or think is interesting. Mollie, let's start with you.

HEMINGWAY: As always, I think Florida is an interesting state to watch, and in the Senate situation there, you heard the national trend the Democrats are going to have this huge wave and they're going to take over all these seats in the House and maybe the Senate. And yet Bill Nelson is struggling in his race and Rick Scott is right there with him. So it is interesting to see how sometimes the national dynamic plays out differently in individual races. And it's also interesting to watch DeSantis running as a really Trump enthusiastic Republican, and I think he's likely to win there. It's just an interesting state to see.

BAIER: Nelson, Scott, neck and neck according to the Real Clear Politics average. Susan, what race did you pick?

PAGE: I'm going to my home state of Kansas, because usually we don't have many toss up races there. It's such a Republican state. You look at the governor's race this time, Kris Kobach barely got through the Republican primary. He's facing Democratic woman challenger, Laura Kelly, with a third candidate in the race, too, an independent candidate, Greg Orman. This race is rated a toss-up even though this is a state that Donald Trump carried by 21 points in 2016. It's worth watching.

BAIER: Yes, don't count out the businessman Orman who has tried before as an independent. OK, Byron, your race?

YORK: I picked the Arizona Senate race because if Democrats win the House, which is very, very, possible, then for Republicans the Senate is going to mean everything. Democrats would only have to win a couple of seats to pick up the House, it does not look good. But Arizona is one of their very few pickup opportunities. Trump won the state, but by less than four points, and they've had a very roiled situation with the Senate. Jeff Flake, the current Republican senator, is not running again because he is so anti-Trump. He's completely out of touch with his party's voters in Arizona. And of course now you've just had the death of Senator McCain and there will be a new Republican senator appointed well before the election. Don't know what effect that could have. So it's a very, very ongoing situation there.

BAIER: As we head past Labor Day we're going to break down all those Senate races that are really interesting. There are a lot of red state Democrats who are facing some pretty tough races. We're going to take a look at those and bring you around the country, take the show on the road as well. Here's one state where things could be up in the air, North Carolina.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JASON HUSSER, ELON UNIVERSITY: We could see a situation where that balance looks a little bit more like North Carolina's slightly reddish purple in which Republicans still get a majority of seats but not the supermajority of seats.

BOB PHILLIPS, COMMON CAUSE NORTH CAROLINA: It essentially dilutes a voter's vote, the power, when you're packing a certain number of particular parties of one district.

PHIL BERGER, (R) NORTH CAROLINA STATE SENATE: The idea we would take the authority to draw these maps out of the hands of the people elected by the people strikes me as just a real distance from where we are and where we ought to be in this country.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: This has to do with redrawing districts, gerrymandering. Susan, this could be a big deal in North Carolina.

PAGE: It could be a big deal in two ways. One way, several Republican members of Congress could be at risk under redrawn districts. It's been a gerrymandered state that has favored the Republican Party since Republicans were drawing district lines. It also could push the election later. It's possible that North Carolina will not be prepared to hold its election on Election Day because of this court fight. If the Supreme Court does not stay the decision and let the vote go ahead with the current district lines, that means they could have the vote in late November, December, even early next year.

BAIER: Byron, if you have the balance of power in the House hanging on five, six races, there's a lot of districts there.

YORK: There are. And you'll have Republicans talking more about judges, because clearly whatever the merits of this case, for the judges to do this so close to the election that the state simply does not have time to actually mount the election in time for the regularly scheduled Election Day. We all knew when it was going to happen. This is really another example of the judges just reaching too far.

BAIER: All right, Mollie?

HEMINGWAY: Yes, it is a divided three-judge panel, meaning only two judges came up with this decision. It throws the entire state into chaos and it disenfranchises an entire state in the name of protecting the voter. The idea that the voters do not get to decide how their districts are drawn through the normal means of electing representatives to draw those is going to be a difficult argument to make. But at the very least, North Carolina should have a way to figure its way through to the next election.

BAIER: We will follow it all. It's getting into interesting times for politics, we love that. Panel, thank you.

When we come back, Britain's prime minister puts on her dancing shoes.

BAIER: The flag at the top of the White House at half-staff in honor of Senator John McCain who gets laid to rest this weekend. Finally tonight, British prime minister Theresa May definitely packed her dancing shoes for her three day trip to Africa.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

(SINGING)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: The British prime minister showing off her dancing skills, sort of, to schoolchildren while in Cape Town, pursuing trade deals ahead of Brexit. Some Brits are taking to Twitter now to actually apologize to South Africa on behalf of the U.K. Others are using the hashtag #May-Bot, and some are asking if the British prime minister is now the dancing queen. We leave it to you.

Thanks for inviting us into your home tonight. That's it for this SPECIAL REPORT, fair, balanced, and still unafraid.

urn:contentItem:5XJC-STT1-F03R-N2PM-00000-00Google joins big tech banking with personal checking accounts2019-11-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:55:45ZLexisNexisGoogle joins big tech banking with personal checking accounts

Nov 14, 2019( IT Pro: http://www.itpro.co.uk Delivered by Newstex) Google is gearing up to launch a personal checking account service via Google Pay, code-named Cache, in partnership with Citigroup.Due to launch in 2020, Cache will compete with rival services from other tech giants challenging the banking industry's supremacy, including Facebook, Apple, Uber, and Amazon.In the past year alone, Facebook has announced itsLibra[1]digital currency project, Apple introduced a credit card, and Amazon laid the groundwork for personal consumer accounts. Each effort has compounded the anxieties of consumers and regulators as big tech branches out into areas traditionally beyond the scope of technology firms.News of Google's Cache comes in the wake of a whistleblower's expos ofProject Nightingale[2], Google's partnership with the largest non-profit healthcare system in the US that granted the tech giant's access to 50 million Americans' medical data. The project spooked plenty of consumers and lawmakers, despite the fact that it technically complied with Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) regulations.On Tuesday[3]German chancellor Angela Merkel warned Europe to reclaim "digital sovereignty" over its data from Silicon Valley tech firms instead of relying on them."So many companies have just outsourced all their data to US companies," Merkel said.

"I'm not saying that's bad in and of itself - I just mean that the value-added products that come out of that, with the help of artificial intelligence, will create dependencies that I'm not sure are a good thing."Google's financial offerings, like its predecessors, are already having trouble getting off the ground. After intense regulator opposition, Facebook's Libra digital currencylost several partners[4]. Meanwhile,charges of discriminatory credit limits[5]have been brought against Apple's credit card partner, Goldman Sachs. Featured Resource The definitive guide to backup for G SuiteHow to find exactly what you need to keep your data safe Download now[6] However, Google's commitment to intimate collaboration with banks might set Google's checking account service apart from its competitors."Our approach is going to be to partner deeply with banks and the financial system," Google executive Caesar Sengupta said, asreported by theGuardian[7]. "It may be the slightly longer path, but it's more sustainable."Google will not sell account holders' financial data, just like it doesn't share Google Pay data with advertisers, according to Sengupta. Whether or not this will be enough to assuage public skepticism of Google's protection of their information is still up in the air. [ 1]: https://www.itpro.co.uk/digital-currency/33857/what-is-libra-a-guide-to-facebooks-cryptocurrency [ 2]:   https://www.itpro.co.uk/privacy/34801/google-partners-with-ascension-to-collect-medical-data-on-millions [ 3]:   https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2019/nov/13/google-checking-accounts-cache-citigroup-bank [ 4]:   https://www.itpro.co.uk/digital-currency/34578/mastercard-and-visa-abandon-support-of-facebooks-libra-cryptocurrency [ 5]:   https://www.itpro.co.uk/technology/artificial-intelligence-ai/34792/apple-co-founder-wozniak-echoes-sexist-apple-card [ 6]:   https://www.itpro.co.uk/cloud/cloud-backup/354051/the-definitive-guide-to-backup-for-g-suite [ 7]:   https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2019/nov/13/google-checking-accounts-cache-citigroup-bank

The project spooked plenty of consumers and lawmakers, despite the fact that it technically complied with Health Insurance Portability and Accountability ...

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XH3-RDK1-JB2G-R1VJ-00000-00Google joins big tech banking with personal checking accounts2019-11-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:55:45ZLexisNexisGoogle joins big tech banking with personal checking accountsKeumarsA

Google is gearing up to launch a personal checking account service via Google Pay, code-named Cache, in partnership with Citigroup.

Due to launch in 2020, Cache will compete with rival services from other tech giants challenging the banking industry's supremacy, including Facebook, Apple, Uber, and Amazon.

In the past year alone, Facebook has announced its Libra digital currency project, Apple introduced a credit card, and Amazon laid the groundwork for personal consumer accounts. Each effort has compounded the anxieties of consumers and regulators as big tech branches out into areas traditionally beyond the scope of technology firms.

News of Google's Cache comes in the wake of a whistleblower's exposé of Project Nightingale, Google's partnership with the largest non-profit healthcare system in the US that granted the tech giant's access to 50 million Americans' medical data. The project spooked plenty of consumers and lawmakers, despite the fact that it technically complied with Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) regulations.

See related 

On TuesdayGerman chancellor Angela Merkel warned Europe to reclaim "digital sovereignty" over its data from Silicon Valley tech firms instead of relying on them.

"So many companies have just outsourced all their data to US companies," Merkel said. "I'm not saying that's bad in and of itself - I just mean that the value-added products that come out of that, with the help of artificial intelligence, will create dependencies that I'm not sure are a good thing."

Companies using Google's G Suite applications are losing data on a regular basis, either due to human error, insider threats, or cyberattacks. Discover the backup solution that helps catch lost data in this whitepaper.

Download now

Google's financial offerings, like its predecessors, are already having trouble getting off the ground. After intense regulator opposition, Facebook's Libra digital currency lost several partners. Meanwhile,   charges of discriminatory credit limits have been brought against Apple's credit card partner, Goldman Sachs.

However, Google's commitment to intimate collaboration with banks might set Google's checking account service apart from its competitors.

"Our approach is going to be to partner deeply with banks and the financial system," Google executive Caesar Sengupta said, as reported by the Guardian. "It may be the slightly longer path, but it's more sustainable."

Google will not sell account holders' financial data, just like it doesn't share Google Pay data with advertisers, according to Sengupta. Whether or not this will be enough to assuage public skepticism of Google's protection of their information is still up in the air.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XH3-B131-JD3N-512R-00000-00Google joins big tech rush to bank accounts2019-11-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:55:45ZLexisNexisWSJPg. 22Google joins big tech rush to bank accountsPeter Rudegeair, Liz Hoffman

Google will soon offer deposit accounts to consumers, becoming the latest Silicon Valley heavyweight to push into finance.

The project, codenamed Cache, is expected to launch next year with accounts run by Citigroup and a credit union at Stanford University, a tiny lender in Google's backyard.

Big tech companies see financial services as a way to get closer to users and glean valuable data. Apple introduced a credit card this northern summer. Amazon.com has talked to banks about offering chequing accounts, which are similar to what Australians refer to as savings accounts. Facebook is working on a digital currency it hopes will up-end global payments.

Their ambitions could challenge incumbent financial-services firms, which fear losing their primacy and customers. They are also likely to stoke a reaction in Washington, where regulators are already investigating whether large technology companies have too much clout.

The tie-ups between banking and technology have sometimes been fraught. Apple irked its credit-card partner, Goldman Sachs, by running ads that said the card was "designed by Apple, not a bank". Major financial companies dropped out of Facebook's crypto project after a regulatory backlash.

Google's approach seems designed to make allies, rather than enemies, in both camps. The financial institutions' brands, not Google's, would be front-and-centre on the accounts, an executive said. And Google will leave the financial plumbing and compliance to the banks - activities it couldn't do without a licence anyway. "Our approach is going to be to partner deeply with banks and the financial system," Google executive Caesar Sengupta said. "It may be the slightly longer path, but it's more sustainable." Google is setting its sights fairly low. Savings accounts are a commoditised product, and people don't switch very often. But they contain a treasure trove of information, including how much money people make, where they shop and what bills they pay.

The company will have to convince a public that is increasingly wary of how tech companies are using personal data that it can be trusted with people's finances. Federal regulators are examining whether the user information Google gets from its search engine, home speakers, email service and other apps gives the company an unfair advantage over competitors.

Mr Sengupta said Google wanted to bring value to consumers, banks and merchants, with services that could include loyalty programs, but it wouldn't sell account users' financial data. The company said it didn't use Google Pay data for advertising purposes and didn't share that data with advertisers.

Fifty-eight per cent of people recently surveyed by consulting firm McKinsey & Co said they would trust financial products from Google. That was better than Apple and Facebook but worse than Amazon.

"If we can help more people do more stuff in a digital way online, it's good for the internet and good for us," Mr Sengupta said.

Mr Sengupta said Google hadn't decided whether the savings accounts would charge fees. Banks sometimes charge fees to some customers who carry smaller balances or don't use their debit cards often.

Big banks already are facing competition from technology upstarts, especially among Millennial, mobile-first customers. Money-transfer services Venmo and Cash App are rolling out debit cards. Chime Financial and Revolut have scored billion-dollar valuations on the backs of their mobile-banking apps.

Google flirted with financial services in the past. In 2011, it launched Google Wallet, where users could digitally store their existing credit cards to make purchases. In 2015, it explored ways to use email to pay bills.Google Pay is on track to have 100 million users worldwide in 2020, up from 39 million in 2018, according to estimates from Juniper Research.

urn:contentItem:5SM9-HY61-DY19-C00X-00000-00Google joins China to battle Amazon2018-06-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:55:45ZLexisNexisGoogle joins China to battle AmazonAngus Grigg and Lisa Murray

The tech titans are lining up for a battle royale in south-east Asia with Google squaring up with Chinese allies to take on Amazon.

Google, which is banned in China, bought into the mainland's second biggest e-commerce player JD.com this week.

It sounds like the height of absurd deal-making until you consider the $US550 million ($746 million) deal for Google's parent, Alphabet, has little to do with China.

It's not really about the money either.

With a market value of $US59 billion and more revenue than Facebook, JD hardly needs Google's spare change to bolster its balance sheet.

What JD does need, however, are allies to fight against its larger and better known rival, Alibaba. Google fits the bill nicely and there is a neat reciprocity because JD can provide exactly the kind of help that Google needs in its latest quest - taking on Amazon.

In a world where the traditional alliance structure is crumbling under the stewardship of the Trump administration, it's more than a little curious to see the resurgence of global alliances in the corporate sphere.

To stretch the analogy a little further, this latest alliance has also been stuck between tech giants in China and the US at the same time as Trump is doing his best to start a trade war between Washington and Beijing.

However that nascent battle plays out, it is unlikely to have a significant impact on the newly-formed alliance between Google and JD, which have teamed up to push into south-east Asia.

For Google, it's about getting the jump on Amazon, which has moved swiftly into India and Japan but has little presence in south-east Asia.

The idea that Google, a search company which makes money from advertising, is being challenged by Amazon, an online retailer, is hard for many to fathom.

But Google itself often cities Amazon as its main competitor.

"More commercial searches are done on Amazon as a starting point for search activity than are done on Google," the company's senior vice-president Kent Walker told ABC radio on Wednesday.

Walker was defending Google against accusations it has too much market power, but his response reveals how traditionally separate categories such as search and e-commerce are rapidly converging.

For Google to play in this space it needs the logistics and warehousing capability of JD, which in turn is trying to match the offshore expansion of its traditional rival Alibaba.

Just this week Jack Ma's internet behemoth, which has a market value of $US528 billion, opened its first south-east Asian office in Kuala Lumpur. Ma himself was there to mark the occasion - while also making a well-publicised call on newly-installed Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad - as the big Chinese tech players increasingly look outside the mainland for growth.

JD, too, has made significant investments in Indonesia, Vietnam and Thailand, where it launched its $US500 million joint venture with local retailer the Central Group just this week.

But the Google tie-up will give it more firepower as the American company brings with it an extensive international user base and strong marketing capabilities. That will help JD better target consumer preferences.

What JD brings to the alliance with Google is its delivery, warehousing and all-round logistics capability.

"That Google has chosen to partner with JD shows its technology is world class," says Adrian Turner, a former Silicon Valley entrepreneur, now chief executive of the federal government's data science agency, Data61.

"It shows that JD knows how to build logistics and do it at scale ... this is what Google is seeking from the deal."

Intellectual property claim

Such an acknowledgement also throws doubt on Trump's often-made claim that the primary goal of many Chinese companies is to steal US intellectual property.

That might still be an issue in other sectors, but when it comes to e-commerce and logistics, JD and Alibaba are recognised world leaders.

This leadership is due to the rapid growth of e-commerce in China, which according to McKinsey accounts for 40 per cent of global transaction value, processes 11 times more mobile payments than the US and has a third of the world's unicorns; start-up companies valued at over $US1 billion.

A spokesman for JD, Josh Gartner, said utilising Google's marketing strength was a key reason for the deal, as the parties seek to become the dominant e-commerce player in south-east Asia.

He also indicated the initial tie-up was just the start.

"When we partner with these companies, we expect the relationship to expand significantly," he said.

Indonesia, with its population of 260 million and an emerging middle class fuelled by economic growth averaging nearly 5 per cent for much of last decade, is the early battleground between JD and Alibaba.

While Alibaba has expanded through acquisition, spending more than $US5.1 billion buying stakes in Indonesia's two biggest e-commerce players Lazada and Tokopedia, JD has preferred to build its own footprint.

It already has five warehouses and 1400 staff across Indonesia and told the local media last month it had plans for a further four warehouses.

Within JD, there is a belief the company can provide a different offering to Alibaba across south-east Asia. In Indonesia, for example, Lazada is viewed as more of a Gumtree-style marketplace where anyone can go on the platform to buy and sell, while JD owns the stock itself and deals with brands directly. Indeed, JD may be moving to get an advantage in the region over Amazon, which has a more similar business model.

Access to Australian products

In addition to Indonesia, JD has bought a stake in Vietnamese e-commerce giant Tiki.vn and earlier this year opened an office in Melbourne, mainly to source food products from Australia and New Zealand.

Alibaba has been equally busy outside Indonesia.

The company, or its affiliate, Ant Financial, have taken positions in e-commerce and payments companies in Singapore, India, the Philippines, Thailand, and Vietnam.

Outside of pure e-commerce, JD has also invested in Indonesian ride-hailing app Go-Jek, alongside Chinese gaming, payments and social media giant Tencent, owner of the ubiquitous WeChat platform.

It's worth noting Tencent also holds a 15 per cent stake in JD, an alliance which has fuelled growth at the online retailer by pushing new shoppers its way.

"I think you need to look at the deal between JD and Google as really a deal between Tencent and Google," says one person who has worked for many of the big tech players in China.

"JD is part of the Tencent ecosystem in China."

That "ecosystem" has seen Tencent, with its $US480 billion market value, compete fiercely with Alibaba for deals and market share in China's rapidly growing tech sector.

In doing so Tencent has put together a series of interlocking alliances which are starting to resemble Europe before World War I.

The initial deal was Tencent taking that 15 per cent stake in JD in March 2014 and online magazine Quartz highlighted during the week a number of subsequent investments and tie-ups. Two years after Tencent's investment, JD bought Walmart's China e-commerce business, which in turn saw the giant US retailer increase its stake in JD to almost 11 per cent.

Google joined the club in August last year when it announced a partnership with Walmart to offer the retailers' products on its online shopping site.

Tencent has since been linked to an investment in the China business of French supermarket chain Carrefour, after the two teamed up on a high-tech store in Shanghai.

Google and Carrefour are also collaborating online, while Walmart said in March it would no longer accept Alibaba's Alipay offering across western China. Instead, it will only accept Tencent's payments option.

In January this year Google and Tencent also agreed to share patents covering a range of products and technologies.

These deals suggest a loose alliance of Tencent, JD, Google, Walmart and potentially Carrefour, while Alibaba and Amazon are mostly going it alone.

Big four in direct competition

When Amazon inevitably moves into south-east Asia, a region which is viewed as five years behind China in its uptake of e-commerce, it will put the world's four largest tech companies in direct competition for the first time.

For Australian meat, vitamin, dairy and wine producers, which all have established relationships with these e-commerce companies, their entry into south-east Asia provides an opportunity.

"Rising middle class in Asia want clean, green, safe food and produce. We do that really well, but for small business it's quite hard today to access south-east Asian markets because there's lots of regulation, logistics and local competition," said PwC's Asia Practice head Andrew Parker, who is on a secondment to Australia Post spearheading its international operations.

"Technology is changing that. You've got these big e-commerce platforms, Alibaba, JD ??? they're putting enormous investment into those markets and I think the Chinese companies have led the way in these areas because they believe that south-east Asia is the next China."

Eventually it may even allow some Australian producers to reduce their reliance on Chinese consumers, but it does also concentrate retail ownership in the region and make producers increasingly reliant on the big the e-commerce giants for their growth and market access.

urn:contentItem:5XDF-JF81-JCMN-Y1VP-00000-00Google just went from being a nobody in wearables to a top player with Fitbit, and that's sure to put an even bigger target on its back (GOOG, GOOGL, FIT)2019-11-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:55:45ZLexisNexisGoogle just went from being a nobody in wearables to a top player with Fitbit, and that's sure to put an even bigger target on its back (GOOG, GOOGL, FIT)Lisa Eadicicco

Nov 01, 2019( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Hollis Johnson/Business Insider Google[1] has acquired smartwatch maker Fitbit[2] for $2.1 billion, giving it a sizeable presence in the wearable technology market. The move comes as lawmakers have been pressuring large tech firms like Google over whether their size and influence has enabled them to become too powerful. Google's software already dominates the smartphone industry, as it holds an 87% grip on the market. Now it owns the third-largest smartwatch company in the world behind Apple and Samsung.

The acquisition could make it difficult for Google to downplay concerns over its size and influence moving forward. Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories.[3] Google and Fitbit announced on Friday that the search giant would acquire the smartwatch[4] maker for approximately $2.1 billion in cash — an acquisition that comes as the Mountain View, California-based tech giant has been under heavy scrutiny from lawmakers worried about the company's size and power. Google's acquisition of Fitbit will bolster its presence in the wearable technology market, a sector that it's largely been absent from as companies like Apple and Fitbit have taken the lead. Google operates a smartwatch software platform called Wear OS that firms like Fossil, Kate Spade, Misfit, and other watch makers have used to power their timepieces, but it doesn't have a flagship product of its own as it does with its line of Pixel smartphones and Pixelbook laptops. Acquiring Fitbit now means that one of the most popular smartwatch brands in the world is part of the Google portfolio, although it's unclear whether the company will continue to let Fitbit operate independently or if it will brand future products under Google's name. The acquisition comes as large tech firms like Google, Apple, Facebook, and Amazon are under more scrutiny than ever over their size and influence. Google already operates the world's most popular mobile platform; its Android software can be found on 87% of smartphones around the world, according to the International Data Corporation[5]. It also claims 58.7% web browser usage through Chrome, says W3Counter[6], a website that monitors website traffic patterns. With Fitbit becoming a part of the company, Google now claims a significant portion of the wearable technology market as well. Fitbit is the second most popular smartwatch maker in the United States, with 24.1% of the market as of the second quarter of 2019, according to Canalys[7]. It's also the third-biggest smartwatch vendor worldwide behind Apple and Samsung according to Strategy Analytics, [8]with 9.8% of the global market as of the second quarter of 2019. That essentially skyrockets Google from being a bit player in the wearables industry to one of the top brands in the world seemingly overnight. The move also means the trove of health data that Fitbit users have shared with the company over the years is now part of Google. That could include data like logs that Fitbit users have created to track their nutrition, weight, and sleep, as well as information that's shared to create a Fitbit account, like date of birth, height, gender, and email addresses. Google said in its announcement that it will not use Fitbit health and wellness data for ad targeting, adding that it will give Fitbit users the option to review, move, and delete their data. Google's big expansion into the wearable tech and health market comes amidst concerns that tech firms are becoming too powerful and may be hampering innovation. Lawmakers questioned executives[9] from Google, Facebook, Amazon, and Apple in July about the size and influence of their businesses. During the hearing, Representative David Cicilline, chairman of the Subcommittee on Antitrust, Commercial, and Administrative Law, said that the internet has become "increasingly concentrated, less open, and growingly hostile to innovation and entrepreneurship." The Department of Justice also announced in July[10] that it will review whether market-leading online platforms are engaging in practices that stifle competition. The press release announcing the probe didn't specify any companies by name, but mentioned it will entail looking at the search, social media, and retail industries — suggesting that firms like Google, Facebook, and Amazon would be at the center of the investigation. Democratic senator Elizabeth Warren also proposed a sweeping plan[11] in March that suggested regulating large tech firms and rolling back certain mergers, such as breaking Instagram and WhatsApp away from Facebook. Google's acquisition of Fitbit will likely only further fuel such scrutiny, and could potentially make it more difficult for the search giant to downplay such concerns in the future.NOW WATCH: Apple just revealed its AirPods Pro for $249, which feature noise cancellation. Here's everything that was wrong with the $159 pair of the wireless headphones.[12]See Also: There's nothing that compares to the Apple Watch, but I'm hopeful Google's Fitbit acquisition will change that[13]Google is buying Fitbit for $2.1 billion[14]How to play WebM files on your iPhone using a free third-party app[15] SEE ALSO:I've been using Apple's new AirPods Pro to see if they live up to urn:contentItem:5XGX-1WB1-F03R-N10M-00000-00Google Launches Checking Accounts In Big Tech's Latest Move On Wall Street2019-11-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:55:45ZLexisNexisGoogle Launches Checking Accounts In Big Tech's Latest Move On Wall StreetZero Hedge

Nov 13, 2019( Phil's Stock World: http://www.philstockworld.com Delivered by Newstex) Courtesy of ZeroHedge[1] View original post here[2]. Move over, Apple. At a time when customers (including the company's co-founder Steve Wozniak) have been non-stop complaining on Twitter about the Apple credit card (brought to you via a partnership with Goldman Sachs), Google has decided that now is the time to make its big leap into the consumer finance business.

According to WSJ[3], Google will soon offer checking accounts to consumers. The project, code-named Cache, is expected to launch next year with accounts run by an interesting partnership: Citigroup, and a small credit union at Stanford University, a tiny lender located in Google's backyard. Big Tech sees finance as the next frontier in their race to monopolize the American economy: It brings users - and their valuable data - closer into the product fold of companies like Google and Apple. Facebook yesterday announced plans to expand its payments app, and its CEO Mark Zuckerberg recently endured another round of Congressional interrogations about its "Libra" cryptocurrency finance project. But regulators, and the banks' army of lobbyists, are already doing whatever they can to slow Silicon Valley's march onto their turf. Unlike Apple's deal with Goldman, Google's project looks more like an equal partnership, with Citigroup getting equal billing for the accounts. In turn, Google will leave the job of navigating the financial plumbing to the banks, making them the interface for all regulatory concerns. In other Google-related news, the company's internal struggle with the 'labor activists' working among its ranks recently led the company to fire one employee for leaking names of staff and personal details to the media. Others were put on leave for allegedly violating company policy, according to Bloomberg[4]. We imagine the army of SJWs who work at Google will love the company's latest decision to jump into bed with the 'evil' Wall Street banks. Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VVG-TG01-DY6Y-M3B4-00000-00Google Launches First Drone Delivery Service in Australia2019-04-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:55:45ZLexisNexisGoogle Launches First Drone Delivery Service in AustraliaGabriela Barkho

Drone deliveries are no longer tales of science fiction.

This week, air delivery developer Wing, owned by Google parent company Alphabet, began delivering its first orders to customers in Canberra, Australia via flying drones.

Subscribe to Observer's Business Newsletter

"Our service allows customers to order a range of items such as fresh food, hot coffee or over-the-counter chemist items on our mobile app, and have them delivered directly to their homes by drone in minutes," the team at Wingannounced. The company, which has been testing out its service in the country since 2014, recently gained approval by local air traffic regulators to perform deliveries.

Among the Wing app's food, household items and over-the-counter medication is droppable gelato, delivered from a local Pure Gelato location, one of the service's launch partners. But it's not just perfect summer day desserts that customers are craving. The flying drones can reportedly have orders dropped off within "minutes" as one Australian customer attested during the project's trial runs, getting sunscreen to her grandchildren in just seven minutes.

As always, when it comes to drone delivery, the aerial vehicles' noise and safety are the main source of controversy surrounding their usage. While Google's pilot program is still in its infancy, it does have to follow specific local policies meant to protect locals from disturbances. For example, the Wing drones cannot fly over main roads or too close to people, and will have to make deliveries during daytime hours. These will include hours of operation between 7 a.m. and 8 p.m. on weekdays.

For safety reasons, the Wing app also gives customers directions on "how to interact" with the drones while receiving goods. Drone delivery is big business for big tech, which is why companies like Google and Amazon continue to invest in them. Wing predicts that its Australian service could bring in as much as $40 million Australian dollars in revenue by 2030. The company plans to expand delivery areas in the coming weeks, with more nearby cities being added soon.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5Y1R-KC81-DYRV-41JG-00000-00Google leader urges balance in artificial intelligence rules2020-01-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:55:45ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. B002Google leader urges balance in artificial intelligence rulesKelvin Chan

1) Google CEO Sundar Pichai raised concerns about potential downsides of AI, a transcript of a speech showed.

LONDON - Google's CEO called Monday for a balanced approach to regulating artificial intelligence, telling a European audience that the technology brings benefits but also "negative consequences." Sundar Pichai's comments came as lawmakers and governments seriously consider putting limits on how artificial intelligence is used. "There is no question in my mind that artificial intelligence needs to be regulated.

The question is how best to approach this," Pichai said, according to a transcript of his speech at a Brussels-based think tank. He noted that there's an important role for governments to play and that as the European Union and the U.S. start drawing up their own approaches to regulation, "international alignment" of any eventual rules will be critical. He did not provide specific proposals. Pichai spoke on the same day he was scheduled to meet the EU's powerful competition regulator, Margrethe Vestager. She also was due to meet Microsoft President Brad Smith separately Monday. Vestager has in previous years hit Google with multibillion-dollar fines for allegedly abusing its market dominance to choke off competition. After being reappointed for a second term last autumn with expanded powers over digital technology policies, Vestager has now set her sights on artificial intelligence and is drawing up rules on its ethical use. Pichai's comments suggest that his company may be hoping to head off a broad-based crackdown by the EU on the technology. Vestager and the EU have been among the more aggressive regulators of big tech companies, an approach U.S. authorities have picked up with investigations into the dominance of companies such as Google, Facebook and Amazon. "Sensible regulation must also take a proportionate approach, balancing potential harms with social opportunities," Pichai said, adding that it could incorporate existing standards such as Europe's tough General Data Protection Regulation rather than starting from scratch. While it promises big benefits, he raised concerns about potential downsides of artificial intelligence, citing as one example its role in facial recognition technology, which can be used to find missing people but also for "nefarious reasons" he didn't specify. In 2018, Google pledged not to use AI in applications related to weapons or surveillance that violates international norms or that work in ways that go against human rights. Also Monday, Pichai was due to meet Frans Timmermans, the EU commissioner overseeing the European Green Deal, the bloc's plan to fight climate change by making the continent carbon neutral by 2050, including through technology. Pichai then was then scheduled to head to the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, this week.
